description: Via an East Anglian dialect, from some Scandinavian (North Germanic) language, related to Danish terne, Norwegian terne, and Swedish tärna, all from Old Norse þerna (“tern; maidservant”), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *þewernǭ (“maidservant; servant’s daughter”), from Proto-Indo-European *tekʷ- (“to run; to flow”). Cognate with Old English stearn. First attested in the 1670s.

entries.meaning: Any of various seabirds of the subfamily Sternidae (of the family Laridae) that are similar to gulls but are smaller and have a forked tail.

description: The noun is derived from Late Middle English terne (“throw of a die or dice showing the number three”), from Old French terne (“gathering of three people; trinity”) (modern French terne), from Latin ternās, the accusative feminine plural of ternī (“three each; three at a time”), from ter (“thrice”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *tréyes (“three”)) + -ī (from -us (suffix forming adjectives)).
The adjective is either derived from the noun, or directly from Latin ternī (“three each; three at a time”); see above.

entries.meaning: (chiefly botany, rare) Consisting of three components; ternate, threefold, triple.
examples: Synonyms: ternary, treble, trine; see also Thesaurus:triple
a tern schooner, one with three masts

definitionGroups.group: (dated or obsolete) A thing with three components; a set of three things.

entries.meaning: (gambling, dated) A lottery prize resulting from the favourable combination of three numbers in the draw.
